intro: Tragacantha membranacea, commonly known as the Persian gum tree, is a flowering plant native to regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers and is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae. The plant produces a resinous sap that has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a natural adhesive. Its leaves are typically trifoliate, with each leaflet being oval-shaped and hairy. Tragacantha membranacea thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils and along riverbanks.
